Title: Support filters for compare
description:
It is very annoying when comparing two java source trees, that all binary files
in that tree are compared too. it would be great to support custom filters for
compare, much like the filters in e.g. package explorer.
using filters, it would be possible to only compare all .java files when
comparing  two trees.

Title: [hovering] Affordance presentation in hover control
description:
1) We should make use of the key binding service for this action, i.e. no 
separate binding. This implies that we query the key binding service for that 
string to be displyed.

2) We should introduce a preference to not show affordances at all (this is 
not juts us).

3) We need to improve the presentation: In the case of a syntax error the 
affordance hint is of the same size as the error message which makes the hover 
heavy weight. Possible solutions: a) Don't show affordance hint if message has 
not been truncated. b) Use a smaller font instead of the default font.

Title: Default Text Font should be fixed-width on Linux-GTK
description:
From Preferences > Workbench > Fonts.

By default, all fonts are derived from "sans" font.
This is a variable-width font appropriate for Banner Font,
Dialog Font and Header Font.  

However, Text Font should be a fixed-width font,
so that the user can draw columns and ASCII art if necessary
in their code comments.

Expected behaviour: 
I recommend Courier-regular-10 or Monospace-regular-10
as a default font for Text Font.

Title: Step with Filters: unify function across languages by allowing filters to be enabled disabled on the 3 basic step functions
description:
Currently, within WebSphere Studio there are a few different yet similar Step
with Filters concepts:

1. JDT offers the standard Step into, Step over, Step Return.  These actions
step without using filters.  The Step with Filters button steps using the
defined filters (defined in the Java->Debug->Step Filters preferences)

2. WebSphere Application Server (WAS) debug uses the Step into, Step over, and
Step return buttons but, by default, a set of filters are applied (to filter out
packages such as com.ibm.websphere.*  that users are not likely to wish to step
into).  The Step with Filters button is disabled. The filters are defined in the
preferences under WAS Debug->Step Filters.

3. Compiled language debug also has the standard Step into, Step over, and Step
return buttons and are used in a similar fashion to JDT.  However, it also has
the concept of "Step Debug".  Users may click on the Step with Filters/Step
Debug button to only step into code that has debug information.  There is
currently no concept of a Step Return for only code that has debug information.


After observing these various Step with Filters scenarios within WebSphere
Studio, we wanted to consider the possibility of achieving a unified solution
for step with filters that could work in a consistent manner for all languages.

One possible solution is as follows:

* Provide users with the three basic step functions: Step into, Step over, and
Step Return
* Provide a mechanism to quickly enable or disable filters on the 3 basic step
functions.  For example, provide a toggle button on the toolbar to
enable/disable step with filters.  This button would toggle stepping with
filters on all 3 step types.  The set of filters, and whether or not they are
enabled by default, would be dependant on the debug target type.  (Note: the 3
basic step functions would have to allow for debug targets that do not support
all of the functions).
* Each debug target could have their own set of default filters (that can be
edited).

This design proposal would remove the "Step with Filters/Step Debug" button and
replace it with an action to enable/disable the Step with filters/Step Debug.

In the JDT case, the step into, step over, and step return buttons would now be
influenced by whether or not the filters are enabled/disabled.  To step
normally, the user may simply click on any of the 3 step types.  If the user
wishes to "Step with Filters" the user would enable the the filters (e.g.,
clicking on the toggle button on the toolbar) and the filters would be applied
to the Step into, Step over, and Step return actions.

In the WebSphere App Server debug (and other similar debug scenarios), the step
with filters should be enabled by default and users can continue to step as they
do now (i.e., not stepping into WebSphere packages, etc.).  If users are
interested in stepping into WebSphere packages, they can disable the filters (or
edit the filters), or set appropriate breakpoints.  

In compiled language debug, users can step normally and choose to enable/disable
step debug as desired.  If step debug is enabled, the Step into will perform
like the current step debug, and step return will now also take the debuggable
information into account (providing additional useful function in the compiled
language scenario, once the engine supports the function;  the step return might
be disabled if filters/step debug are enabled until the engine supports the
function).

Title: Ant 1.6 new options
description:
Ant 1.6 has introduced new options:
-noinput              do not allow interactive input
-keep-going, -k       execute all targets that do not depend on failed target(s)

Title: Job.schedule() should optionally run even if it is currently running
description:
Currently if you call schedule() on a job that is already running the 
scheduling is ignored. The problem with this is if you are using the job to 
refresh refreshes can be lost if they come in too late.

We should optionally be able to schedule in such a way that the job always 
reschedules after completion if schedule was called while it was running.

Title: Typing is slow
description:
On my 400 MHz G4 everything that involves typing is slow, typically it takes 
somewhere between 1/10 to 1/2 second for a keystroke to have any effect (when 
editing, issuing commands, even arrowing around a list). During this time the 
status bar will flicker (once per keystroke). It is easy to fill up the key 
buffer.

Title: Performance issues with Ant editor: slow to open
description:
Sometimes it take a very long time to open an Ant editor for XML files. 

I think that the issues can be related to XML parser used by the editor and DTD
or scheme definition linked from an XML file. My PC is behind a firewall, so
parser always fails to load external DTD or schema (i.e from bea.com or sun.com
or w3c.org) but it take a while to complete.

Please disable loading of the external DTD's and Schemas or make this a
configurable preference.

It also can be related to the size of XML file, please review

Title: Move to using ProjectHelper2
description:
Currently we have a derived class ProjectHelperImpl that slightly extends the 
Apache Ant ProjectHelperImpl class to be able to parse based on a String 
instead of a file.

In Ant 1.6, there is a new class ProjectHelper2 which still does not allow 
parsing based on strings (or InputStreams) but it is a SAX 2 based reader as 
opposed the older implementation that is SAX 1 (which has large chunks 
deprecated).

And since we are redoing / checking all the Xerces stuff anyways...

Title: Option to hide properties in Ant outline view
description:
Similar to the current Hide Internal Targets, I'd like to be able to Hide 
Properties as well so that all I see are external targets.

Title: [Workbench] Disable of autobuild on Workbench#init no longer needed
description:
In the Workbench#init(String[] commandLineArgs, final Display display) method, 
the disable of the autobuild while editors are opened should no longer be 
needed since autobuilds are now done in the background. Actually, keeping the 
disable in is a problem because, on startup, the workbench blocks (busycursor) 
while the build is taking place, making the user wait needlessly.

Title: Cycles in string substitutions
description:
Our string substitution engine does not detect cycles when resolving strings 
recursively. This could result in an infinite loop.

Title: [ssh2] provide key generation tools
description: The cvsssh2 plugin solves most of the problem of interacting with CVS via ssh2: notably it removes the need for the user to install and configure an external ssh2 and ssh-agent. But even with that the user must generate and install keypairs, which * is non-trivial. E.g. start @ http://sourceforge.net/docman/display_doc.php?docid=761&group_id=1#keygen and skip the SF-specific content. * requires external tools (i.e. Cygwin ssh-keygen) Thus cvsssh2 represents only a partial solution to the ssh2 problem. I would like to see a more complete one, wherein one or more Eclipse plugins assists the user with 1 keypair generation. Note that JSch (the cvsssh2 folks) may already have work in this direction: http://www.jcraft.com/jsch/index.html > TODO > * generating RSA, DSA key pairs. 2 keypair installation. Given the keypairs, local install (creating something that works like a ~/.ssh) is pretty trivial: save to local dir, and point to it. (See Windows>Preferences>Team>CVS>CVSSSH2.) Remote install is trickier, but Jsch appears to already support scp and sftp, and you already have org.eclipse.team.ftp, so again existing work could be leveraged. With this functionality, Eclipse would ease another barrier to entry to participation in OSS and IIOSB projects. I also realize you already have things to do, but it also seems that, in this case, existing pieces need only to be "glued together." TIA, Tom Roche, Rational Studio Model2 Tooling, abbotforswt admin

Title: Checkbox table view for external tools
description:
For enabling and disabling external tool builders, I think it would be less 
clumsy if the builder page was like the breakpoints view: a checkbox table 
viewer and we remove the enable/diable buttons.

Title: Move to Ant 1.6
description: I think that if Ant 1.6 is found to be stable enough, it should be part of Eclipse 3.0. Eclipse is currently using Ant 1.5.4 (see bug 41277) As of October 17, 2003, 1.6beta2 is out. I imagine that the full release will be out well before the scheduled May 7, 2004 release of Eclipse 3.0. My primary concern at the moment is because 1.6 fixes this bug (http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=10499). That bug causes the javac task to fail when using fork, and a source directory with a space in it. There are also tons of other bug fixes and new features that I am sure will make lots of other people happy. The sooner Ant 1.6 get in, the better.

Title: 3.0 ContentAssistant change breaks code assist auto activation
description:
In 3.0 (I believe this happened around M4/M5, but I know it's broken in M5 and
M6) the ContentAssistant changed from being a VerifyKeyListener to a
KeyListener. The unintended (I hope) consequence of this is that the content
assistant is now notified of key changes _after_ the text viewer instead of
before. This means that, if the user types a character,
fViewer.getSelectedRange().x previously reported the position before the
character and now reports the position after the character.

If that weren't enough problem, in 3.0 the document partitioner has also been
run prior to notifying the content assistant. The combination of the two means
that instead of a key being evaluated in the context (partition) in which it was
typed, it is now evaluated in the context that the key, itself, establishes!

The result is a major, breaking change to the way auto-activation works.

For a simple example, try an XML editor like XMLBuddy that auto-activates when
the '<' character is typed in a text-type partition. E.g., if you have a
document with cursor positioned as indicated by the | character.

<root>
  |
</root>

and type a '<' character, in 2.0/2.1 the activation characters were determined
by the text partition the cursor was in before the change. In 3.0, the
activation characters are determined by the tag partition the cursor is in after
the change.

Title: [RCP] Marker images not painted in left ruler
description:
Neither of my marker types show an icon in my subclass of TextEditor. The
problem appears to be that in M6 no annotations directly held in fAnnotations in
an AnnotationModel are painted.

This looks like a bug. When called from doPaint(), getAnnotationIterator() calls
the new method getAnnotationIterator(boolean cleanup, boolean recurse). The
javadoc says that recurse tells "whether annotations of attached sub-models
should also be returned." However the code uses recurse to determine whether
annotations of attached sub-models should _instead_ be returned.

It appears that getAnnotationIterator(boolean cleanup) should be called whether
or not recurse is true; if recurse is true, the iterator should be added to the
list of iterators collected from the sub-models.

Title: editor outline should have icon for macrodef
description:
The <macrodef> and <presetdef> tasks (new in ant 1.6) allow build file authors
to write reusable ant routines much more effectively than was possible in the
past. Since these tasks have a special significance to build file authoring they
should probably receive their own icon in the outline view. Another candidates
is <import>. 

While it could be agrued that <macrodef> is actually a task and that it would be
breaking the convention to give it its own icon, from the perspective of an a
build file author, <macrodef> more closely resembles a target than a task.

Title: code assist should include previously defined properties
description:
Code assist for properties should not include only well-known property names but
also properties that have been defined else inside the build file via a
<property> tag. Similarly code assist should supply a list of previously defined
fileset, or path ids when using the attribute refid="". 

Eventually we may want to add support for property names defined within a
property file. A dialog could allow build file authors to specify a list of
property files from which to draw property names for a particular build file.

The code assist for elements ought also to include macrodefs which have been
defined. Of course macrodefs could be defined in an imported file, and so a
later enhancement of this functionality might allow a build file author to
specify additional files from which to pull macrodefs.

When writing the depends="" attribute of a target, code assist should supply a
list of targets defined within the build file. As in the senarios above, a
target might appear in an imported file or entity include. At a later date this
functionality could be extended to handle such cases.

While writing this enhancement in such a way as to grab every applicable
property, macrodef, target, etc. would be difficult if not impossible, even a
relatively simple and incomplete implementation of this functionality would be
helpful to users which spend a great deal of time authoring build files.

Title: CVS Modules with ampersand (&) do not appear in HEAD listing
description:
If you use the modules file in your CVSROOT to define modules composed of other 
modules, these modules will not appear in the HEAD revision listing, inside of 
the CVS repository exploring view

for example:

this module entry in our CVS server results in a module link in the HEAD 
listing correctly:

    ptplace-webapp ptbroker/web-apps/ptplace

but this one does not show up:
    ptplace-all ptbroker &gen_bundle &colinx_xml &ptplace &ptplace_images

The module checks out fine on the command line.

I am using eclipse 3.0 M6, however I observed this to be broken on 3.0 M3, M4, 
and M5.  It _did_ work back on 2.x -- I suspect it was broken when the 
background thread stuff was added.

More platform details:

* Jdk 1.4.1_01
* eclipse version 3.0 M6
* windows 2000

Title: acquiring a second rule while waiting for first
description:
Build: 3.0 M6

Stack trace below.  The short summary:

- thread tries to acquire rule "A".
- Rule is not available, so "A" is added to the rule stack and the thread blocks
- While the thread blocks, the progress monitor is checked for cancelation
- The default monitor spins the event loop to keep the UI alive and allow the
user to cancel
- If an event in the event loop now tries to acquire rule "B" which is available,
it will throw an exception because B cannot be pushed above incomptable rule "A".

Possible solution: don't push the rule onto the stack until it is safely
acquired.  That way a thread can safely acquire and release a different rule
while it is waiting.

Question: this doesn't seem to cause a hold and wait (thus opening the door to
deadlock), but I need to convince myself that this is safe.

Title: commits denied by CVS access control are not reported or handled by Eclipse
description:
In our configuration, we use CVSNT for our version control and control 
repsitory access via the CVS access control lists.

We have spotted, on more than one occasion, that Eclipse does not behave 
properly in cases where CVS commits are denied because the commit user does 
not have the correct write permissions.

What happens is that, when CVS correctly denies the commit, Eclipse does not 
report any problems - and then continues to behave as though the commit has 
been successful.

By that I mean that the Update operations (etc) all appear to support the fact 
that the commit was successful - despite the fact that the loaded file is now 
different in Eclipse to the repository (the repository does not change, 
because the commit failed, but the Eclipse editor maintains the edits that 
were done - and insists that it has the correct, clean, latest revision).

I am reporting this as something I have seen on more than one machine, but do 
not have ability to reproduce at the moment to give further information.

Problem has been noted with Eclipse 2.1 and 3.0.

Steps to reproduce would be something along the lines of:

Check out a project
Make changes to a file
Run CHACL to remove write permission for your user from the project's 
repository/module
Commit the changes to the file

I don't believe it makes a difference whether the user's write permissions are 
set before or after the checkout - I do not have CVS admin rights to 
investigate this further

promote the Java-specific views they need.

views when the user's selection in the debug view changes. In order to not be 
too invasive, this should be presented as a preference ("Link Views to 
Selection") on the Debug View.

I propose creating an extension point that would allow debugger contributers to 
map their debug model identifier to the collection of views that are applicable. 
For example, Java could list "Breakpoints, Variables, and Display" and C could 
list "Breakpoints, Variables, and Registers". When the user selects an item in 
the Debug View, we can promote (activate) any of the applicable views that are 
currently being obscured by non-applicable views.

description:
I20030113

Title: [ViewMgmt] API to close a view without instantiating it
description:
IWorkbenchPage should provide an API for closing a view without instantiating 
it. IWorkbenchPage#hideView(String viewId), to complement 
IWorkbenchPage#showView(String viewId).

Without this API, clients have to instantiate views before closing them. This 
could mean a lot of work loading plug-ins just to close a view.

This API is particularly useful for the Debuggers work related to 
opening/closing views in the Debug Perspective in response to context changes.

Title: [implementation] cannot re-install InformationPresenter after uninstall

call SourceViewer.configure more than once.  In my configure, I uninstall the 
previous SourceViewer components like PresentationReconciler, ContentAssistant, 
and InformationPresenter before I retrieve the new ones from the

uninstalling and then reinstalling the same objects.  I am able to do this 
successfully with PresentationReconciler and ContentAssistant, however, I

setting the fDisposed flag to true.  But when I call install() again, the

Title: [ViewMgmt] API for promoting views on a stack
description:
In Debugland, we'd like to present the user with relevant views when they switch 
between debugged languages (represented as contexts).

In our current implementation, I end up with a handful of view IDs that are
considered applicable for the currently selected stack frame in the Debug
view. The goal is to make as many of the views in this collection visible
as possible.

The problem I'm having is that I haven't found any API related to how views
are currently stacked (tabbed). For example, say I have views A, B, and C
stacked on top of each other. Views A and B are both be in the collection
of "applicable views," so we'd like to make sure one of them is visible.
Also, we want to make sure that if either of these views is currently
visible, that view will be the one that's chosen so it will stay on top.

An API to programatically determine that views A and B are stacked would solve 
our problem.

description:

this method is used by both Compare and Team to provide a context menu action

situation. This would involve either changing the spec on the method or

lot of work either. I wanted to run it by UI for an opinion before proceeding.

Title: No "Environment" tab on program project builders
description:
The Ant and Program Builder tab groups don't have the environment tab. Since the 
underlying delegates already support environment variables, the builders should 
have these tabs too.

Title: "Run" in Outline View does not work for default target
description:
Using "Run" in the Outline View does not work for the default-target, because
AntRunTargetAction uses AntTargetNode.getLabel() which has the string "
[default]" appended to the targets name and therefore is not a valid target-name
to run.

Changing this to "getTarget().getName()" fixes that (see attached patch)

Title: Outline positions to wrong offset in editor
description:
N20040207

While calculating the offset for positioning in the editor a forward search is
used. Because the parser returns the line/column where the currently parsed tag
ends the offset for the next open tag in the file is calculated. 

Backward search should be used. (see patch)

Title: [Console] move to new generic console API
description:
org.eclipse.ui.console has support for creating consoles and showing them in a
dedicated console view. The CVS console should be moved to this new API.
